thread.title: Woman with $200,000 in savings can't buy Sydney home
thread.title_full: Woman with $200,000 in savings can't buy Sydney home | Daily Mail Online

author: Sinead Maclaughlin For Daily Mail Australia
title: Woman with $200,000 in savings can't buy Sydney home
text:
A successful entrepreneur with more than $200,000 in savings says she is still is struggling to enter the property market – as the average price for a Sydney property rockets past the $1 million mark.
Wenee Yap, 30, currently spends $460-a-week on rent for an inner-city studio apartment in Sydney with her partner, she spoke to Daily Mail Australia about her frustrations trying to climb the property ladder.
'I actually stayed at home to save until I was 26, much longer than I had expected to but I saved 160,000 - but it just wasn't enough.'
Wenee Yap, 30, (pictured) has more than $200,000 in savings says she is still is struggling to enter Sydney's property market
Despite earning between a respectable $60,000-$90,000 a year, depending on her client work, business and teaching law – the co-founder of Sydney’s first cat cafe Catmosphere has been unable to buy 'even the smallest shoebox'.
'I was looking about five years ago and now I kick myself I didn’t bite the bullet and buy a place.
'At the time I decided to consolidate my savings, I didn't expect house prices to rise as they have.'
Ms Yap spoke of a friend who earns more than $150,000 a year as a senior associate in major law firm, while her husband works in a large Australian bank - they're also struggling to find a home in Sydney.
'I think there's this idea if you don’t own your property you’re falling behind, it's like the Australian way of life.'
But Ms Yap now believes now is not the right time to buy anyway, saying there is too much 'irrationality in the markets'.
'There is sense of resentful insanity. People are taking out loans they can’t pay off for 30 or 40 years to get onto the property ladder.
'But maybe the ladder on fire.'
But Ms Yap now believes now is not the right time to buy anyway, saying there is too much 'irrationality in the markets'
A study labelled Sydney's housing market 'severely unaffordable,' ranking the city above other famously expensive ones like London and New York
Sydney has clocked in as the second most expensive city to buy property in the world, with a median house price of $1.1 million dollars.
The city was described as 'severely unaffordable', and was knocked out of the top spot only by Hong Kong – beating London, Los Angeles and New York.
A study labelled the NSW capital's housing market 'severely unaffordable,' ranking the city above other famously expensive ones like London and New York.
'In Hong Kong it makes sense it's unaffordable, it's a tiny island,' Ms Yap told Daily Mail Australia.
'We’re in Australia, there's so much space. It doesn’t seem rational that property should be so expensive.
Sydney has clocked in as the second most expensive city to buy property in the world, with a median house price of $1.1 million dollars
'We’re in Australia, there's so much space. It doesn’t seem rational that property should be so expensive,' Ms Yap said
'Sydney is in a Looney Tunes category,' said Hugh Pavletich, a co-author of the Demographia International Housing Affordability Survey.
The survey compares major housing markets based on the 'median multiple,' a figure that is derived by dividing median house prices by median household incomes.
Sydney scored a median multiple of 12.2, which means that a household would need to pool its gross annual income for 12 years to pay for a home up-front.
Demographia considers a score of three or less affordable; anything over five is rated 'severely unaffordable'.
'These are lunatic figures, there's no other way to describe it,' Mr Pavletich told Daily Mail Australia.
He went on to call Sydney's housing market 'a crisis situation.'
